facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1343 and 1473 of 1971 filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1343 and 1473 of 1971. Appeals by special leave from the judgments

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgments and orders dated September 3, 1971 and August 6, 1971 of the Delhi High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgments and orders dated September 3, 1971 and August 6, 1971 of the Delhi High Court in I.A. No. 1170 of 1971 in Election Petition No. 1 of 1971 and Election Petition No. 2 of 1971.

facts.text: Delhi High Court orders in I.A. No. 1170 of 1971 in Election Petition No. 1 of 1971 and Election Petition No. 2 of 1971.

anchor.surface_text: in I.A. No. 1170 of 1971 in Election Petition No. 1 of 1971 and Election Petition No. 2 of 1971. K. Daphtary, M. C. Bhandare and C. M. Oberoi, for the appellant  in C.A. No. 1343 of 1971 .

facts.text: Andley J. of Delhi High Court permitted inspection of ballot papers polled during the last general election to the Lok Sabha.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals by special leave arise from the decision of Andley J.  Delhi High Court  permitting inspection of the ballot papers polled during the last general election to the Lok Sabha held last March in the South Delhi Constituency and the Delhi-Sadar Constituency.

facts.text: General election to Lok Sabha held last March in South Delhi Constituency and Delhi-Sadar Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: held last March in the South Delhi Constituency and the Delhi-Sadar Constituency. The appellants are the successful candidates.

facts.text: Appellants are successful candidates who contested on behalf of Congress party with symbol cow and calf.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are the successful candidates. They company- tested in the two companystituencies mentioned earlier on behalf of the ruling Congress party. Their symbol was company and calf.

facts.text: Nearest rivals were Jan Sangh candidates with symbol Deepak.

anchor.surface_text: Their nearest rivals were the Jan Sangh numberinees whose symbol was Deepak. The appellants were declared elected.

facts.text: Appellants declared elected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were declared elected. The unsuccessful Jan-Sangh candidates have challenged the validity of the election of the appellants.

facts.text: Unsuccessful Jan-Sangh candidates challenged validity of appellants' election.

anchor.surface_text: The unsuccessful Jan-Sangh candidates have challenged the validity of the election of the appellants. The main ground pleaded in support of the election petition was that the ruling party had rigged the election.

facts.text: Election petitioners alleged ruling party rigged election using chemically treated ballot papers stamped with invisible ink.

anchor.surface_text: The process adopted in rigging the election, according to the election petitioners is a somewhat companyplicated one. That process was explained to us thus Millions of ballot papers were chemically treated the symbol of the companygress candidates in those ballot papers was mechanically stamped by using invisible ink.

facts.text: Chemical treatment caused polling marks to disappear and pre-stamped symbols to emerge.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the chemical treatment of those ballot papers, the mark put at the time of the polling disappeared after a few days and the stamping mechanically placed earlier emerged.

facts.text: Alleged conspiracy between ruling party and Election Commission.

anchor.surface_text: The suggestion was that this was done as a result of a companyspiracy between the ruling party and the Election Commission.

facts.text: Election Commission instructed Returning Officers to forward substantial number of ballot papers to Delhi ostensibly for scrutiny.

anchor.surface_text: To carry out the design in question, we were told that quite companytrary to the earlier practice, the Election Commission instructed the Returning Officers to forward to Delhi a substantial number of ballot papers of each companystituency, ostensibly for the purpose of scrutiny but really for the purpose of carrying out the design mentioned earlier,

facts.text: Returning Officers supplied with chemically treated and mechanically stamped ballot papers in place of originals.

anchor.surface_text: According to them in place of the ballot papers received, the Returning Officers were supplied with the ballot papers chemically treated and mechanically stamped. Those ballot papers formed a part of the ballot papers used at the election.

facts.text: Election Commission provided larger interval between polling and counting.

anchor.surface_text: It was further said that in furtherance of the above design, the Eelection Com- mission made two alterations in the practice followed earlier. Firstly it provided a larger interval between the date of polling and the date of companynting

facts.text: Election Commission altered rule for mixing ballot papers of various booths and rotating in drums.

anchor.surface_text: and secondly by precipitate alteration of a rule, it provided for mixing up of the ballot papers of various. booths and rotating them in drums.

facts.text: At counting, large number of ballot papers had different color from others.

anchor.surface_text: In those petitions it was alleged that at the time of the companynting, it was numbericed that the companyour of a large number of ballot papers was different from the companyour of the other ballot papers,

facts.text: Stamping of symbols on those ballot papers was uniform at identical spot.

anchor.surface_text: stamping of, the symbols in those ballot papers was uniform, at an identical spot in each of those ballot papers, the stamps were uniform in density and they looked bright and fresh.

facts.text: Stamps uniform in density, bright and fresh, dissimilar to other papers.

anchor.surface_text: the stamps were uniform in density and they looked bright and fresh. Those features were quite dissimilar to those found in the other papers including those companytaining votes in favour of the defeated candidates.

facts.text: Election petitioners filed affidavits of two persons present at counting supporting observations.

anchor.surface_text: They have filed affidavits of two persons who claim to have been present at the time of companynting. They supported the allegations in the petitions seeking inspection regarding the facts said to have been observed at the time of companynting

facts.text: Rumours prevailing about rigging of election.

anchor.surface_text: The election petitioners in this companynection referred to the rumours prevailing about the rigging of the election,

facts.text: Landslide victory of ruling party wholly unexpected.

anchor.surface_text: the landslide victory of the ruling party which according to them was wholly unexpected

facts.text: Huge quantity of unused ballot papers found in godown in Chandigarh.

anchor.surface_text: and finding of huge quantity of unused ballot papers in a godown in Chandigarh.

facts.text: Election petitioners have no direct evidence, seek to prove by examination of ballot papers.

anchor.surface_text: The election petitioners do number claim to have any direct evidence to support their version. They seek to prove their version primarily on the basis of the examination of the ballot papers.

facts.text: Delhi High Court did not hold allegations not bona fide.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial judge did number hold that the allegations made by the election petitioners were number bona fide allegations.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds allegations serious, material facts call for investigation.

anchor.surface_text: He took the view that those allegations were of serious character and the material facts stated in suport of those allegations were such as to call for investigation into the truth of those allegations. We are of the same opinion.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses appeals subject to directions for limited inspection of ballot papers.

anchor.surface_text: Subject to the directions given above, these appeals are dismissed but in the circumstances of the case we make numberorder as to companyts in these appeals.

facts.text: Court directs selection of about 600 ballot papers polled by each returned candidate and 200 for petitioners for initial examination.

anchor.surface_text: For finding out whether there is any basis for those allegations, it would be sufficient if some ballot papers, say about 600 out of those polled by each of the returned candidates are selected from different bundles, or tins in such a way as to get a true picture. He may also select-about 200 ballot papers cast in favour of the election petitioners for companyparison.

facts.text: No written objection filed during counting to acceptance of ballot papers as spurious.

anchor.surface_text: It was further urged that at the time of companynting, the attention of. the Returning Officer was number invited to the strange features mentioned earlier number was the acceptance of any of those ballot papers objected to on the ground that they were spurious ballot papers.

facts.text: Election petitioners claim they invited attention of Assistant Returning Officer to features.

anchor.surface_text: According to the election petitioners, they did invite the attention of the Assistant Returning Officer to the various features mentioned by them.

arguments.claim: Allegations of rigging are nothing but propaganda stunts and wholly devoid of truth

anchor.surface_text: It was said, on behalf of the appellants that those allegations were nothing but propaganda stunts and they were wholly devoid of truth. If that is so, it is in public interest that the falsity of that propaganda should be exposed.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: except on very good grounds, inspection of ballot papers should number be allowed and the petitioners have failed to make out a case for inspection.

arguments.court_reasoning: Serious allegations require scrutiny to expose falsity if untrue, maintain public confidence in electoral process

anchor.surface_text: In Ram Sewak Yadav v. Hussain Kamil Kidwai... This Court ruled that by the mere production of the sealed boxes, the ballot papers did not become part of the record and they were not liable to be inspected unless the Tribunal was satisfied that such inspection was in the circumstances of the case necessary in the interests of justice.

arguments.claim: Dr. Jagjit Singh: Tribunal has CPC powers for inspection but must have concise material facts, not vague; secrecy important; no roving inquiry; interests of justice overriding

anchor.surface_text: In Dr. Jagjit Singh v. Giani Kartar Singh... The overriding test laid down there is the interests of justice... The allegations in support of a prayer for inspection must not be vague or indefinite they must be supported by material facts and prayer made must be a bona fide one.

arguments.claim: Jitendra Bahadur Singh: Vague indefinite allegations without material facts, no inspection even with affidavit

anchor.surface_text: The last decision relied on by the appellant is Jitendra Bahadur Singh v. Krishna Behari... This Court came to the conclusion that relevant allegations were vague and indefinite they were not supported by material facts and there was no basis for coming to the conclusion that inspection of the ballot papers was necessary.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ot papers. This was number a claim put forward in the election petition. The High Court allowed the inspection and permitted the scrutiny solely on th

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished: unlike there, here specific material facts from counting observations

arguments.claim: Allegations cannot be proved/disproved except by inspecting ballot papers

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the appeals we enquired with the Counsel for the appellants whether the allegation regarding the chemical treatment of the ballot papers can be proved in any other manner than, by inspecting the ballot papers. We got no satisfactory reply to our query.

arguments.claim: No hard and fast rule for inspection; depends on facts of each case, overriding aim complete justice

anchor.surface_text: We do not propose to lay down any hard and fast rule in this matter indeed, to attempt to lay down such a rule would be inexpedient and unreasonable... In a matter like allowing inspection of ballot papers, no rigid rules have been laid down, no can be laid down. Much depends on the facts of each case.

arguments.claim: Serious allegations challenge integrity of EC, undermine public confidence if true; expose falsity if untrue in public interest

anchor.surface_text: The allegation that our electoral process has been fouled is a very serious allegation, That allegation is a challenge to the integrity and impartiality of the Election Commission. Those allegations if believed are sure to undermine the confidence of our people in our democratic institutions... If that is so, it is in public interest that the falsity of that propaganda should be exposed.

arguments.claim: General inspection not necessary; limited sample (600 per returned candidate, 200 for petitioners) sufficient to test basis

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether it is necessary to inspect all the ballot papers as has been ordered by the trial judge. We think that a general inspection should not be permitted... For finding out whether there is any basis for those allegations, it would be sufficient if some ballot papers, say about 600 out of those polled by each of the returned candidates...

arguments.claim: Secrecy of ballot important but must yield where interests of justice require inspection on bona fide material allegations

anchor.surface_text: It is no doubt true that a judge while deciding the question of inspection of ballot papers must bear in mind the importance of the secrecy of the ballot papers. The allegations in support of a prayer for inspection must not be vague or indefinite they must be supported by material facts... Secrecy of ballot is important, but doing justice is undoubtedly more important...

arguments.claim: Tribunal has powers under RPA S92/CPC for discovery/inspection of ballot papers

anchor.surface_text: Section 92 of the Act which defines the powers of the Tribunal, in terms, confers on it, by cl. (a), the powers which are vested in a Court under the Code of Civil Procedure when trying a suit, inter alia, in respect of discovery and inspection.

holdings.text: The allegations made by the election petitioners are of serious character and bona fide, with material facts calling for investigation into their truth.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial judge did not hold that the allegations made by the election petitioners were not bona fide allegations. He took the view that those allegations were of serious character and the material facts stated in suport of those allegations were such as to call for investigation into the truth of those allegations. We are of the same opinion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with trial judge; material facts from counting observations sufficient under S.88(a) RPA, not vague.

holdings.text: Failure to object to ballot papers at counting or inform Returning Officer does not estop election petitioners from raising allegations in the election petition.

anchor.surface_text: it does not estop the Election petitioners from taking the pleas in question in the election petitions though undoubtedly it is a circumstance to be considered on the question of the value to be attached to the allegations made

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relevant to credibility but not estoppel; not decisive at interlocutory stage.

holdings.text: Inspection of ballot papers is necessary in the interests of justice given serious bona fide allegations supported by material facts.

anchor.surface_text: inspection of ballot papers should be allowed only when the court thinks that it is necessary in the interests of justice

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overriding test from precedents (Ram Sewak Yadav, Dr. Jagjit Singh) satisfied here; public interest in verifying rigging claims challenging EC integrity.

holdings.text: Election tribunal has powers under Section 92 RPA equivalent to civil court under CPC for discovery and inspection of ballot papers.

anchor.surface_text: Section 92 of the Act which defines the powers of the Tribunal, in terms, confers on it, by cl. (a), the powers which are vested in a Court under the Code of Civil Procedure when trying a suit, inter alia, in respect of discovery and inspection.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of statutory provision as interpreted in Dr. Jagjit Singh.

holdings.text: No hard and fast or rigid rules can be laid down for ordering inspection of ballot papers; decision depends on facts of each case and interests of justice.

anchor.surface_text: We do not propose to lay down any hard and fast rule in this matter indeed, to attempt to lay down such a rule would be inexpedient and unreasonable. In a matter like allowing inspection of ballot papers, no rigid rules have been laid down, no can be laid down.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms flexibility from precedents; overriding aim complete justice.

holdings.text: Importance of ballot secrecy must be borne in mind but yields where interests of justice require inspection based on bona fide material allegations.

anchor.surface_text: It is no doubt true that a judge while deciding the question of inspection of ballot papers must bear in mind the importance of the secrecy of the ballot papers. ... Secrecy of ballot is important, but doing justice is undoubtedly more important

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balancing test from Dr. Jagjit Singh; here justice prevails over secrecy.

holdings.text: General inspection of all ballot papers not permitted; limited sample inspection (600 for each returned candidate, 200 for petitioners) sufficient initially to test allegations.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Proportionality to avoid fishing inquiry; if basis found, further probe possible.

holdings.text: During inspection, care must be taken to maintain secrecy of the ballot.

anchor.surface_text: But in doing so he will take care to maintain the secrecy of the ballot.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural direction safeguarding secrecy while allowing inspection.

holdings.text: Appeals against High Court order permitting inspection dismissed, subject to modification for limited inspection as directed.

anchor.surface_text: Subject to the directions given above, these appeals are dismissed but in the circumstances of the case we make no order as to costs in these appeals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court substantially correct; modified for proportionality and secrecy.

precedents.case_name: Dr. Jagjit Singh v. Giani Kartar Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: in a proper case Tribunal can order inspection of ballot papers but allegations must contain concise statement of material facts, not be vague or general, importance of secrecy of ballot, no roving or fishing enquiry, overriding test is interests of justice
precedents.cited_holding: The true legal position in this matter is numberlonger in doubt. Section 92 of the Act which defines the powers of the Tribunal... Vague or general allegations... would number serve the purpose... application must give material facts... importance of the secrecy of the ballot papers cannot be ignored...

precedents.citation: Jitendra Bahadur Singh v. Krishna Behari and ors. 1 1970 1. S.C.R. 852

anchor.surface_text: The last decision relied on by the appellant is Jitendra Bahadur Singh v. Krishna Behari and ors.  1 . To this decision one of us was a party. There an elector  1st respondent in that appeal  challenged the election of the appellant to the Lok Sabha. He alleged, inter alia, in the election petition that there were improper rejection and improper reception of votes. In the  1  1970 1. S.C.R. 852.

precedents.case_name: Jitendra Bahadur Singh v. Krishna Behari
precedents.cited_proposition: vague and indefinite allegations not supported by material facts do not justify inspection of ballot papers
precedents.cited_holding: relevant allegations were vague and indefinite they were number supported by material facts and there was number basis for companying to the companyclusion that inspection of the ballot papers was necessary for doing justice between the parties

anchor.surface_text: Subject to the directions given above, these appeals are dismissed but in the circumstances of the case we make numberorder as to companyts in these appeals.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals dismissed subject to directions for preliminary limited inspection of sample ballot papers instead of general inspection; no order as to costs
directions: A general inspection should not be permitted until satisfactory proof; select about 600 ballot papers out of those polled by each returned candidate from different bundles or tins to get true picture
Select about 200 ballot papers cast in favour of election petitioners for comparison
All selected ballot papers examined at first instance by learned judge with assistance of counsel for parties and parties
